metadata.synopsis: Jaheira's default dialogue. Topics range from her past life to her current goals as they develop. Unless otherwise stated, her tone is confident and to the point. She's a seasoned adventurer with a sardonic sense of humour - and a little less cynical than she might present herself to be.

35.speaker: Jaheira
35.text: I grow tired of these false faces. Every corner we turn, another - and now it is my face they use to turn Minsc against us.
35.context: NodeContext: Quiet anger. Her low point - not quite giving in to desperation, but almost - coming out as frustration instead.

33.speaker: Jaheira
33.text: I am sorry, but... I am just tired.
33.context: NodeContext: Anger tailing off into tiredness for real - her low point

46.speaker: Player
46.text: Enough sulking, Harper. Now's not the time to grow soft.

66.speaker: Jaheira
66.text: ...A terrible rallying speech. No poetry. Not even a little pat on the head.

24.speaker: Player
24.text: Why? We know Minsc is alive - now we just have to find him.

5.speaker: Jaheira
5.text: It is some defect of the mind, I think - to stubbornly insist you are following the light, even as you blunder through the darkness.

54.speaker: Jaheira
54.text: Or perhaps the defect is mine.

2.speaker: Player
2.text: Maybe we should have killed him while we had the opening.

60.speaker: Jaheira
60.text: Probably we should have - and yet we both stayed our hands.

38.speaker: Player
38.text: Of course you're tired - you're ancient. But we still have work to do.

72.speaker: Jaheira
72.text: When I left Minsc to this fate, I believed I had no choice. I believe it still - we were ignorant of our enemy, unarmed against the cult.
72.context: CinematicNodeContext: Pausing to take a deep breath - then telling us what's actually bothering her.NodeContext: Pausing to take a deep breath, telling us what's actually been gnawing at her all this time

13.speaker: Jaheira
13.text: I made the right decision. But... I do not like how easily I made it. Minsc would have never left me behind, no matter what happened.

44.speaker: Jaheira
44.text: That is his problem entire. The past century left Minsc unchanged. And so he believes the world has never changed - that I have not.

16.speaker: Jaheira
16.text: You saw the fool - hanging on the doppelganger's every word, for no other reason than that it wears my face.

3.speaker: Player
3.text: The cult has other ways of controlling people. Infection, indoctrination...

78.speaker: Jaheira
78.text: Hah, you think I flatter myself in believing it is my face alone that Minsc follows? Malar mark me, but I find myself hoping he is tadpoled.

41.speaker: Player
41.text: You don't have to explain, Jaheira. You're worried for your friend - it's not a crime.

37.speaker: Jaheira
37.text: No, but snotting into my sleeve while there is still work to do is.

28.speaker: Player
28.text: Maybe you haven't changed as much as you think.

15.speaker: Jaheira
15.text: I... am sure you meant that to be comforting.

4.speaker: Jaheira
4.text: Come, then. We need a lead - and bullying this banker ought to make me feel better.

56.speaker: Jaheira
56.text: Come, then. We need a lead on where these shapeshifters have fled to - let us see what hints they left behind in the vault.

71.speaker: Player
71.text: It doesn't matter. We have to find him.

23.speaker: Jaheira
23.text: You focus on the goal while I slobber on about things I cannot change. Irritating.

70.speaker: Jaheira
70.text: The Counting House. More bastion than bank, I'm afraid.

50.speaker: Jaheira
50.text: Minsc must have a way in, but he's never had much use for coin beyond whatever sharp steel it could buy.

14.speaker: Jaheira
14.text: There must be something in the vaults the great Chosen are after. All the more reason to get there - swiftly.

1.speaker: Player
1.text: So you do believe he's working for the cult?

32.speaker: Jaheira
32.text: I have no reason to doubt the guildmaster's information. Only her conclusions.

68.speaker: Jaheira
68.text: The Stone Lord she describes sounds nothing like Minsc. As for the name, well... a bad joke, perhaps.

67.speaker: Jaheira
67.text: The Time of Troubles ended almost a century and a half ago. I weathered the years between with all the elven grace you have no doubt come to expect.

53.speaker: Jaheira
53.text: But do you know how Minsc - a human - passed those years? I'll give you a hint: they named him the 'Beloved Ranger'.

57.speaker: Narrator
57.text: *You recall the urban myth that trickled through the Lower City fest-halls some years back - a hero who had been turned into a statue, returning to life in the city's hour of need.*

6.speaker: Player
6.text: So he's some hero of prophecy?

12.speaker: Jaheira
12.text: No. He is an idiot who pissed off some gutter-mage with a flair for petrification. To this day, I still don't know all the details.

58.speaker: Player
58.text: Ah. 'Stone Lord'. That's a little on the nose.

48.speaker: Jaheira
48.text: For Minsc, it is downright subtle. He shrugged at the whole affair - I still don't know how he came to be petrified.

40.speaker: Player
40.text: How could he have been stuck that way for a century?

10.speaker: Jaheira
10.text: Because who would question a statue to our friend, thinking Minsc of Rashemen had returned to a hero's welcome in Rashemen?

25.speaker: Jaheira
25.text: I don't even know how he was freed. Harper work would take me from the city - sometimes for years at a time.

30.speaker: Jaheira
30.text: The few occasions I visited his monument, well... I took it as a moment for reflection. To think of old friends, and the fight I had to continue in their name.

65.speaker: Jaheira
65.text: And during all my self-serious brooding that big, dumb, insufferable buffoon was staring me in the face.

59.speaker: Player
59.text: And you stared right back without even realising it was him.

62.speaker: Jaheira
62.text: I did. On occasion, I even found myself critiquing the stone-work. 'Surely his head was not so large as this?'

7.speaker: Jaheira
7.text: I cannot call myself a particularly good friend. But I am his friend - and I cannot let Nine-Fingers have him.

26.speaker: Player
26.text: You abandoned him for a century. It's understandable you don't want to do it again.

22.speaker: Jaheira
22.text: So dramatic. 'Abandoned' is a strong word, for one.

18.speaker: Jaheira
18.text: Just... help me save him. You might see why I didn't question a bit of peace and quiet.

64.speaker: Player
64.text: You have to admit - that's a little funny.

17.speaker: Jaheira
17.text: That was much Minsc's feeling, too. Perhaps I shouldn't be working so hard to bring you two together.

51.speaker: Player
51.text: Don't worry. We'll save him - it might not even take a hundred years this time.

73.speaker: Jaheira
73.text: I hope you find yourself amusing, at least. Come, then - to the Counting House.

11.speaker: Jaheira
11.text: Assuming Minsc has not since tripped and fallen into a demi-plane, or some such.

31.speaker: Player
31.text: Are you sure you want to find him? It sounds like he's cursed.

45.speaker: Jaheira
45.text: For every strange situation he finds himself in, he wanders right back out of it again. Just a century later, sometimes.

55.speaker: Narrator
55.text: *The name strikes a dim memory: a monument to a hero on one of the city's squares, which had turned out to be the hero himself, frozen in stone until the city's hour of need.*

29.speaker: Jaheira
29.text: No? It was a statue, dedicated to one of the city's lost heroes. Only it was that hero - Minsc, frozen in stone for a century. And freed, the story goes, in the city's hour of need.

69.speaker: Player
69.text: What do you know of the Stone Lord?

47.speaker: Jaheira
47.text: Only what we heard from Keene. He seems to have sprung up while we were out in the shadow-lands.

27.speaker: Player
27.text: Are you sure we shouldn't just let the Guild take care of this?

52.speaker: Jaheira
52.text: I do not think there will be much care involved, if we let Nine-Fingers get to him first.

21.speaker: Player
21.text: Then that's what we'll do. But I wanted to discuss something else.
